instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
hey guys, '

i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no backlight i have already replaced backlight filter (F7700), have also replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, LCD Connector, <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>, and nearly everything else around there, and back of the board, 

and i know i should try to understand it, but i have spent hours on it and nothing, i still believe is something simple but you guys please help! :)


<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>

1- 8.6
2- 8.6
3- 2.82
4- 8.6
5- 8.6
6- 8.6

<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>

1- 0
2- 3.3
3- 0
4- 0
5- 3.3
6- 0

F7700

8.6 on both sides

thank you in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
Post voltage on both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>.
Check XW7720 bridge integrity.
Use search function on the forum; pictures available too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message: Maybe its the Panel.. Have you tested it with a known good one ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> - 8.58V on both sides

Known good Panel/display

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
Post some voltages dor <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>; VIN; VDDIO, EN, PWM.
Use surrounding components as test points.

Did you check XW7720?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
PWM - 0.57
EN- 2.83
VDDIO- couldnt find it
VIN- 8.58

and pardon my stupidity, but dont know how to check XW7720, i see it on the board view,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
"Use search function on the forum; pictures available too..."
[url]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/search?q=xw7720&searchJSON=%7B%22keywords%22%3A%22xw7720%22%7D[/url]

Remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>.
If you get backlight, do PRAM reset few times.
Remove the wire, resolder <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
i removed <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and ran wire from <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> to PWM, and no backlight, did reset pram a few times, and nothing, 

also checked XW7720 , <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> pin 1 to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> Pin 5, and there is continuity, so i think bridge integrity is ok, :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
Post resistance to ground on all <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> connections.
That will denote a bad solder, if is the case.
Do you get image?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no backlight
threads.message:
Use diode mode, instead of ohm scale; red probe at ground.
And post values for <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_X</SIGNAL> lines.
